conclusion: Determine the instantaneous value of the induced current and the average value of the induced EMF as the wire frame rotates.
The induced EMF in a rotating loop is given by Faraday's Law: \( \mathcal{E} = -\frac{d\Phi}{dt} \).
Magnetic flux \( \Phi \) through the loop is \( \Phi = B \cdot S \cdot \cos(\theta) \).
The angle \( \theta \) changes with time as \( \theta = \omega t \).
Differentiating \( \Phi \) with respect to time gives \( \mathcal{E} = B \cdot S \cdot \omega \cdot \sin(\omega t) \).
The induced current \( I \) is given by \( I = \frac{B \cdot S \cdot \omega \cdot \sin(\omega t)}{R} \).
The average EMF over a time interval \( \Delta t \) is \( \langle \mathcal{E} \rangle = \frac{1}{\Delta t} \int_{0}^{\Delta t} \mathcal{E}(t) \, dt \).
The time interval for a 60° rotation is \( \Delta t = \frac{\pi}{3\omega} \).
Evaluate the integral \( \int_{0}^{\Delta t} \sin(\omega t) \, dt = \frac{1/2}{\omega} \).
Instantaneous value of the induced current: \( I = \frac{\sqrt{3} B \cdot S \cdot \omega}{2R} \).
Average value of the induced EMF: \( \langle \mathcal{E} \rangle = \frac{3B \cdot S \cdot \omega}{2\pi} \).
